content: The "Email Privacy Act" may be cited as the short title of this Act. It includes provisions for voluntary disclosure corrections. The "Email Privacy Act" amends Section 2702 of title 18, United States Code, regarding disclosure of electronic storage information. The "Email Privacy Act" amends Section 2702 of title 18, United States Code, regarding disclosure of electronic storage information. The amendment includes changes to language such as replacing "divulge" with "disclose" and "a provider of" with "a person or entity providing." It also clarifies the recipients of communication information and adds the term "wire or electronic" before communication in subsection (b). The "Email Privacy Act" amends Section 2702 of title 18, United States Code by updating language, specifying lawful consent for disclosure of communication information, and adding "wire or electronic" before communication in subsection (c). The Email Privacy Act updates Section 2702 of title 18, United States Code by specifying lawful consent for disclosure of communication information. Section 2703 of title 18, United States Code is amended to require a warrant for disclosure of electronic communication contents in storage with a provider, issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. The provider must promptly respond to a warrant for disclosure to a governmental entity if no date is specified. A warrant issued by a court of competent jurisdiction is required for a governmental entity to obtain the contents of a wire or electronic communication stored with a remote computing service. The provider must promptly respond to a warrant for disclosure to a governmental entity if no date is specified. The warrant must be issued by a court of competent jurisdiction and applies to stored wire or electronic communications received from or created by a subscriber or customer of the remote computing service. The government can request disclosure of records or information from a provider of electronic communication or remote computing service regarding a subscriber or customer, excluding the contents of communications, for the purpose of providing storage or computer processing services. Governmental entities can obtain disclosure of records or information from electronic communication providers under specific conditions, such as obtaining a warrant issued by a court of competent jurisdiction, a court order, lawful consent of the subscriber or customer, or as otherwise authorized. Governmental entities can obtain subscriber or customer information from electronic communication providers through various legal means, including subpoenas authorized by Federal or State statutes, grand juries, trials, or civil discovery. This information may include the name, address, telephone records, service length, and subscriber identity. Governmental entities can obtain subscriber or customer information from electronic communication providers through legal means, including subpoenas authorized by Federal or State statutes. This information may include subscriber identity, service length, and payment details. The governmental entity receiving this information is not required to provide notice to the subscriber or customer. The section allows electronic communication providers to notify subscribers of legal requests for information, and it clarifies that governmental entities can use various legal processes to obtain information from providers. The section grants jurisdiction to require disclosure of wire or electronic communications by originators, addressees, or recipients, as well as by electronic communication service providers to governmental entities. The section allows for disclosure of wire or electronic communications by individuals or entities, including remote computing or electronic communication service providers, to governmental entities. It also clarifies that Congress retains the power to compel production of such communications stored by these service providers. SEC. 4. DELAYED NOTICE. Section 2705 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to allow a governmental entity to request a court order for delayed notification to a provider of electronic communication service or remote computing service. The court can grant a request for up to 180 days if there is reason to believe that immediate notification may endanger an individual's life, result in flight from prosecution, or lead to destruction of evidence. The amended Section 2705 of title 18, United States Code allows a governmental entity to request a court order for delayed notification to a provider of electronic communication service or remote computing service. The court can grant extensions of up to 180 days each if there is reason to believe that immediate notification may endanger an individual's life, result in flight from prosecution, or lead to destruction of evidence, tampering with evidence, intimidation of witnesses, or jeopardizing an investigation. SEC. 5. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. The Act does not prevent the US Government from acquiring wire or electronic communication contents or subscriber information under existing lawful authorities like the Wiretap Act or the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. The Act does not prevent the US Government from acquiring wire or electronic communication contents or subscriber information under existing lawful authorities like the Wiretap Act or the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. This includes title 18 (commonly known as the "Wiretap Act") or any other provision of Federal law not specifically amended by this Act.
